Rationale: Private property is heavily restricted; land and major industries are state-owned under the Juche socialist system.
Central planning dominates allocation; black markets exist but are suppressed, and official allocation is state-directed.
Profit-seeking is criminalized outside state channels; individual accumulation is equated with counter-revolutionary behavior.
The Public Distribution System centrally allocates food and goods by political loyalty tier (songbun); elites receive disproportionate share.
Nominal universal services (healthcare, housing, education) are provided, but quality and access vary widely and are tied to loyalty.
Leadership has passed through the Kim family across three generations with near-total hereditary fidelity; songbun status is inherited.
Political and ideological variation is forbidden; deviation from Juche is punished as treason.
Loyalist families and military elites persist through generations; disloyalty leads to purge or labor camps.
The regime itself functions as an extractive parasitic layer on the population; internal parasitism by non-elite actors is suppressed, but systemic top-down extraction is normalized.
Political and economic competition is structurally eliminated; all organs are subordinated to Kim authority.
Regime has survived sanctions and isolation through repression and Chinese patronage, but population survival rates during the 1990s famine were catastrophically poor.
Nuclear deterrence and strategic brinkmanship create a security niche at the cost of economic and demographic vitality.
Borders are among the world's hardest; defection is punishable by execution or gulag.
Policy failures (famine, stagnation) are denied or blamed externally; internal correction is rare and punitive.
Massive surveillance and mutual monitoring enforce loyalty; cheater detection serves regime control rather than system health.
Power is centralized; institutional modularity is suppressed in favor of monolithic party-state-military unity.
State-controlled archives and propaganda preserve regime narrative; independent knowledge is restricted.
Juche ideology enforces near-total cultural homogeneity through education and propaganda.
Kimilsungism-Kimjongilism is the sole permitted ideological framework.
Political dissent is met with extreme suppression via labor camps and collective punishment.
Families are subject to collective punishment for political crimes of members.
Independent religious practice is prohibited; state-controlled churches are performative.
Art serves state ideology; unauthorized production is criminal.
Science is directed toward regime-priority projects (nuclear, missiles); basic research is suppressed.
Education centers on ideological indoctrination and loyalty to the Kim dynasty.
All media is state-owned; foreign media possession is criminalized.
Songun (military-first) policy prioritizes armed forces in resource allocation.
Regime maintains near-total diplomatic and economic isolation by design.
Constant emphasis on U.S. and South Korean hostility legitimizes internal repression.
Succession operates through opaque hereditary designation with no institutional mechanism.
Kim family cult of personality is among the most extreme in history.
Frequent purges of elites to maintain control.
State rhetorically encourages population growth for military needs; resource shortages limit effectiveness.
Emigration is prohibited; internal movement is tightly regulated.
Regime promotes ethnic homogeneity and restricts foreign integration.
